docs.lead_paragraph: Campaigning Republicans thought they could coast into office on a wave of public fury over health care reform. They thought wrong.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes Republican congressional candidates are struggling to come up with coherent positions on the health care reform law, given growing public recognition that it is working; contends Republicans' positions on the law are murky; welcomes fact that some Democratic candidates are beginning to campaign on the law's benefits.
docs.snippet: Campaigning Republicans thought they could coast into office on a wave of public fury over health care reform. They thought wrong.

docs.lead_paragraph: Veterans have expressed frustration with delayed access to health care and an impenetrable and unresponsive bureaucracy at Veterans Affairs hospitals and clinics.

headline.main: Many Veterans Praise Care, but All Hate the Wait
headline.print_headline: Many Veterans Praise Care, but All Hate the Wait

docs.abstract: Hundreds of veterans around country respond to questionnaire on The New York Times website, expressing frustration with delayed access to medical care and impenetrable and unresponsive bureaucracy at Veterans Affairs hospitals and clinics; complaints are made even as many praise quality of care; comments give voice to findings that medical center officials used variety of schemes to hide increasingly long wait time for medical care.
docs.snippet: Veterans have expressed frustration with delayed access to health care and an impenetrable and unresponsive bureaucracy at Veterans Affairs hospitals and clinics.

byline.contributor: Jonathan Higuera contributed reporting from Phoenix.

docs.lead_paragraph: The European Union extended full employment rights to Romania and Bulgaria this year, sparking unfounded fears in Britain of a flood of desperate immigrants.

headline.main: Britain’s New Immigrants, From Romania and Bulgaria, Face Hostilities
headline.print_headline: Britain’s New Immigrants, From Romania and Bulgaria, Face Hostilities

docs.abstract: European Union's decision to extend full employment rights to Romania and Bulgaria sparks unfounded fears in Britain of a flood of desperate immigrants; Office for National Statistics reports that the number of Romanians and Bulgarians working in Britain from January to March of 2014 actually dropped, from 144,000 in the previous quarter to 140,000.
docs.snippet: The European Union extended full employment rights to Romania and Bulgaria this year, sparking unfounded fears in Britain of a flood of desperate immigrants.

docs.lead_paragraph: From Lex Luthor to J. R. Ewing, pop culture had always taught me that rich guys were total jerks. Then my little brother made a fortune.

headline.main: The Moat, the Millions and the $50 Timex Watch
headline.print_headline: The Moat, the Millions, and the $50 Timex Watch

docs.abstract: Eric Spitznagel Riff essay reflects on fact that much of popular culture had inculcated him with idea that rich people were bad people; recounts having to reassess that impression after his brother became extremely wealthy.
docs.snippet: From Lex Luthor to J. R. Ewing, pop culture had always taught me that rich guys were total jerks. Then my little brother made a fortune.

docs.lead_paragraph: Patricia Lockwood turns sexts and rape jokes and other Internet flotsam into pure poetry.

headline.main: The Smutty-Metaphor Queen of Lawrence, Kansas
headline.print_headline: The Smutty-Metaphor Queen of Lawrence, Kansas

docs.abstract: Jesse Lichtenstein article profiles poet Patricia Lockwood, who finds herself on verge of literary fame after her book Balloon Pop Outlaw Black became the best-selling small-press poetry book of 2013; notes Lockwood's next book Motherland Fatherland HomelandSexuals has been published.
docs.snippet: Patricia Lockwood turns sexts and rape jokes and other Internet flotsam into pure poetry.
